engagementHook.title: From Crime Scenes to Cures
engagementHook.content: In 1984, Alec Jeffreys developed DNA fingerprinting—a technique that would revolutionise forensic science. Since then, biotechnology has solved crimes, produced life-saving medicines like insulin, created drought-resistant crops, and even helped identify victims of disasters. The cellular biology you've learned is the foundation of these transformative technologies.

keyConcepts.definition: A technique that rapidly amplifies specific DNA sequences, creating millions of copies from a small sample for analysis or manipulation.
A laboratory technique that separates DNA fragments by size using an electric field applied to a gel matrix, with smaller fragments moving faster.
The direct manipulation of an organism's genes using biotechnology techniques to introduce, remove, or modify DNA sequences.
DNA molecules formed by combining genetic material from multiple sources, such as inserting a human gene into a bacterial plasmid.
A revolutionary gene-editing technology that uses guide RNA to target specific DNA sequences and the Cas9 enzyme to make precise cuts for gene modification.

contentSections.title: PCR: Amplifying DNA
contentSections.content:
Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) revolutionised molecular biology by enabling rapid DNA amplification. The process involves three steps repeated in cycles:

  • Denaturation (95°C): Heat separates the double-stranded DNA into single strands.
  • Annealing (50-65°C): Primers bind to specific target sequences on the DNA template.
  • Extension (72°C): DNA polymerase synthesises new DNA strands starting from the primers.

Each cycle doubles the DNA amount, so 30 cycles produce over 1 billion copies. PCR is essential for DNA sequencing, forensics, disease diagnosis, and ancient DNA analysis.

contentSections.title: Gel Electrophoresis: Separating DNA
contentSections.content: Gel electrophoresis separates DNA fragments based on size. DNA samples are loaded into wells at the negative electrode end of a gel. When electric current is applied, the negatively charged DNA migrates toward the positive electrode. Smaller fragments move faster through the gel matrix than larger ones.
keyPoints: DNA is negatively charged due to phosphate groups
Agarose gel acts as a molecular sieve
DNA is visualised using fluorescent dyes like ethidium bromide
DNA ladders with known sizes are used for comparison
contentSections.example: DNA fingerprinting in criminal investigations uses gel electrophoresis to compare samples.

contentSections.title: Applications and Ethics
contentSections.content:
Biotechnology has transformed multiple fields:

  • Medicine: Production of insulin, growth hormones, and vaccines; gene therapy for genetic diseases; personalised medicine based on genetic profiles.
  • Agriculture: Genetically modified crops with pest resistance, improved nutrition, or drought tolerance.
  • Forensics: DNA profiling for criminal identification and paternity testing.
  • Research: Understanding gene function, disease mechanisms, and evolutionary relationships.

Ethical considerations include concerns about GMO safety, genetic privacy, access to genetic therapies, and the potential for genetic discrimination.

multipleChoice.question: What is the purpose of the denaturation step in PCR?
options: To add primers to the DNA
To separate the double-stranded DNA into single strands
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: To separate the double-stranded DNA into single strands

multipleChoice.question: In gel electrophoresis, why do smaller DNA fragments move faster through the gel?
options: They navigate through gel pores more easily
They are attracted more strongly to the negative electrode
They have more fluorescent dye attached
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: They navigate through gel pores more easily
